catalyst.source: Ag-NPs-promoted TiO 2 nanowires (TiO 2 NWs) core/shell hetero-junction with plasmonic properties for selective CO production in photo-induced CO 2 -hydrogen system has been investigated.
catalyst.context: Ag-NPs-promoted TiO 2 nanowires (TiO 2 NWs) core/shell hetero-junction with plasmonic properties for selective CO production in photo-induced CO 2 -hydrogen system has been investigated.Ag-NPs were photo-deposited over the TiO 2 NWs and characterized by XRD, TEM, N 2 -adsorption-desorption, XPS, UV-vis and PL spectroscopy.Ag-NPs in metal-state were successfully coated on the TiO 2 NWs surface, producing core-shell hetero-junction.Ag-NPs coated over TiO 2 NWs exhibited strong absorption of visible light due to localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) excitation, trapped electrons and hindered charges recombination rate.The synergistic effect of Ag-NPs coated over TiO 2 NWs for CO 2 conversion was evaluated in a gas-phase system under UV and visible light irradiation.The plasmonic Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs demonstrated excellent photoactivity in the reduction of CO 2 into CO, CH 4 and CH 3 OH under visible light irradiation.The results show that 3 wt.Ag-NPs-loaded TiO 2 NWs was found to be the most active, giving the highest CO evolution of 983 mmole-g-catal.A1 h A1 at selectivity 98.This amount of CO produced was 23 times more than the TiO 2 NWs and 109 times larger than the yield of CO produced over the pure TiO 2 .More importantly, the quantum yield was substantially enhanced for CO evolution.The LSPR excitation and synergic effect of Ag-NPs which can effectively accelerate the charge separation was proposed to be responsible for the enhancement of photocatalytic activity.The photo-stability of Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs evidenced in cyclic runs for selective CO production under visible light, yet photoactivity declined over the irradiation time under UV-light.The reaction mechanism to describe the reaction pathways is also presented.

catalyst.context: The TiO 2 NWs were prepared via a facile synthesis route according to our previous work 38.Typically, 1 g of TiO 2 powder was suspended in 8 M NaOH solution, stirred for 10 min and then transferred into 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave.The solution was stirred continuously at 110 C for 2 h using a stirred tank reactor and then cooled to room temperature.The solids obtained were washed with deionized water and 0.1 M HCl several times to reach pH below 9.After being dried, the products were calcined at 500 C for 5 h.Ag-NPs coated over TiO 2 NWs were prepared by photo-deposition method and the amount of Ag-NPs in each sample was controlled by the concentration of AgNO 3 solution.For the deposition of silver (Ag-NPs) on the TiO 2 NWs, 0.50 g of TiO 2 powder was dispersed in 20 mL of water and then a certain volume of 0.025 M AgNO 3 solution was added into it.The solution was photo-irradiated for 15 min using 200 W Hg lamp of light intensity 150 mW/cm 2 at wavelength 252 nm to get gray precipitations.The precipitates obtained were filtered, dried and calcined at 500 C for 5 h.The different volumes of AgNO 3 solution were used to get Ag loading in TiO 2 of 1, 2, 3 and 5 wt., respectively.The pure TiO 2 NWs were synthesized using the same procedure.The schematic illustrations for fabrication of Ag-NPs loaded TiO 2 NWs is depicted shown in Fig. 1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was recorded on a Bruker D 8 advance diffractometer with Cu-Ka radiation (l 1.54 A, operated at 40 kV and 40 mA) to identify the phase structures and phase transformation of all the samples.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed using JEOL-TEM apparatus operating with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV, which was used to measure the particle sizes and d-spacing of the sample.The XPS spectra were calibrated with respect to the binding energy of the C1 s signal at 284.60 eV as the internal standard.Nitrogen-adsorptiondesorption isotherms were collected using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 at 77 K, after degassing the samples at 523 K for 4 h under vacuum and using the nitrogen flux.The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore diameters were calculated from the desorption branch of isotherms according to BJH method.Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) diffuse reflectance absorbance spectra were carried out on a Cary 100 Agilent UV-vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrated sphere in the wavelength range of 200-800 nm.Raman and photoluminescence (PL) spectra of samples were recorded on a Raman Xplora Plus Spectrophotometer (HORIBA Scientific) with a 600 nm grating and a 532 nm emitting laser as an excitation source. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 was carried out in a photocatalytic reactor of volume 108 cm 3 .A 35 W car HID lamp was used as a visible light source with a light intensity 20 mW/cm 2 measured using a reference solar cell (91150 V, Newport).The photoactivity was further investigated using a solar simulator LCS-100 (Newport) integrated with UV-cut filters with light intensity equal to one solar spectrum.Similarly, a 200 W Hg reflector lamp with a light intensity of 150 mW/cm 2 was used as a source of UV-light irradiation.The UV-light intensity was measured using an online optical process monitor ILT OPM-1D and a SED008/W sensor.The lamps were located at the top of the reactor equipped with a quartz window of 10 mm thickness for passing of light irradiations.Typically, 10 mg powder photocatalyst was dispersed uniformly at the bottom of the reactor and was purged using helium (He) as a carrier gas.Compressed CO 2 and H 2 (purity 99.99) were regulated by mass flow controllers (MFC).The reactor pressure was maintained at 0.20 bar above the atmospheric pressure for the batch mode experiment by closing the outlet valves.The gas feed ratio of CO 2 and H 2 of 1 was used for all the experiments.For CO 2 reduction under continuous flow operation, gas mixture was continuously passed through the reactor at a total gas flow rate of 20 mL/min.The operating conditions used were CO 2 /H 2 feed ratio 1.0, temperature 100 C and pressure 1 atm. The CO 2 reduction products were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (GC-Agilent Technologies 6890 N, USA) equipped with FID and TCD detectors (GC/FID/TCD).FID detector was connected with a HP-PLOT Q capillary column (Agilent, length TCD detector was connected to UCW982, DC-200, Porapak Q and Mol Sieve 5A columns.Similarly, Porapak Q and DC-200 columns were used for separation of C 1 -C 5 compounds while light gasses (H 2 , O 2 , N 2 , CO) were separated using MS-5A column.215).This illustrates pure anatase phase of TiO 2 with growth axis in (101) directions.The diffraction peaks for Ag-NPs were not detected, which may result from the low-loading content or fine dispersion of Ag-NPs on the surface of TiO 2 crystal.The patterns revealed that the photo-deposition of Ag-NPs did not affect the crystal structure of TiO 2 .Similar observations have been reported previously 39.

catalyst.source: The Ag-NPs deposited TiO 2 NWs core-shell hetero-junction was successfully investigated for selective CO 2 photoreduction to CO under UV and visible light irradiations.
catalyst.context: The Ag-NPs deposited TiO 2 NWs core-shell hetero-junction was successfully investigated for selective CO 2 photoreduction to CO under UV and visible light irradiations.The photocatalytic CO evolution rates were significantly enhanced in the presence of Ag-NPs as a shell on TiO 2 NWs.The CO production rate is up to 983 mmole g-catal.A1 h A1 at selectivity 98 and apparent quantum yield of 0.15.The other products detected in adequate amounts were CH 4 and CH 3 OH.Stability test confirmed prolonged stability of Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs for selective CO production under visible light irradiations.The improved photocatalytic activity of Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs is ascribed to the synergic effect, charger transfer property and the SPR effect of Ag-NPs.

light source.context: Fig. 2(b) depicts Raman spectra of the pure TiO 2 and Ag-loaded TiO 2 NWs samples.The characteristics bands of TiO 2 NPs and TiO 2 NWs samples have similar reflections, and the peaks are relatively sharp and stronger than the Ag-loaded TiO 2 NWs samples.In pure TiO 2 , the intense Raman signals with E g(1) mode appeared at 143 cm A1 followed by low intense modes E g( 2) and E g(3) located at 196 cm A1 and 635 cm A1 , respectively.B 1g peak appeared at 394 cm A1 and (A 1g B 1g ) reflected as a single merged peak at 511 cm A1 .All these peaks reveal the characteristics of the pure anatase phase of TiO 2 21.The Raman spectra of Ag-NPs loaded TiO 2 NWs samples are identical to that of the pure TiO 2 NWs, which clearly indicated that the TiO 2 retained its structure after incorporation of these metals.However, Ag NPs relating signals were not identified because of the relatively low concentrations and due to the weak Raman scattering of these metals.However, changes are obvious in the position and width of the Ag NPs modified TiO 2 peaks.With the loading of Ag NPs, the Raman band E g(1) is slightly shifted towards higher wavenumber, Raman band B 1g and E g(3) was broadened and their intensities were reduced.This indicated that the interaction between Ag-NPs and TiO 2 NWs affected the Raman resonance of the TiO 2 .These observations have confirmed successful deposition of Ag-NPs over the TiO 2 NWs surface without any phase change. The morphology of Ag-NPs-loaded TiO 2 NWs is examined using TEM as illustrated in Fig. 3. Fig. 3(a-c) show uniform distribution of Ag-NPs over the surface of TiO 2 NWs.The TiO 2 NWs detected were of different size with diameter in the range of 20-50 nm.The particle size distribution of Ag-NPs is depicted in Fig. 3(b), which revealed Ag-NPs are very fine, with diameter range of 1.3-14 nm.Two mean diameters were detected with their values of 2 nm and 8 nm, respectively.The amounts of large size plasmonic Ag-NPs existing in the sample are approximately the same as the small size Ag-NPs.More importantly, the small size Ag-NPs presented over the TiO 2 NWs surface can serve as electrons sink to promote the charges separation.Fig. 3(d) exhibits the crystal structure of the Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs hybrids measured using a high resolution TEM.The spacing between two adjacent lattice fringes to (101) plane of anatase TiO 2 and (111) plane of Ag-NP were 0.35 nm and 0.24 nm, respectively. The N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the pure TiO 2 , TiO 2 NWs and Ag-NPs modified TiO 2 NWs samples are depicted in Fig. 4. The isotherms of the pure TiO 2 , TiO 2 NWs and Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs are similar to type IV curve with the hysteresis loops which is the characteristics of mesoporous materials.The BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the TiO 2 , TiO 2 NWs and modified TiO 2 NWs samples are summarized in Table 1.BET specific surface area (S BET ) of the pure TiO 2 was 42 increased to 72 m 2 g A1 for TiO 2 NWs.On the other hand, BET surface area gradually decreased to 48 m 2 g A1 when 3 wt.Ag-NPs was loaded to TiO 2 NWs.This decreased in the BET surface area could be accounted for partial TiO 2 NWs surface coverage by the deposited Ag-NPs.Similar observations were obtained in BJH adsorption pore volumes.In the case of pore diameter, pure TiO 2 pore diameter was 10 nm, increased to 25 nm in TiO 2 NWs, obviously due to the larger diameter of TiO 2 NWs.A further increase in pore diameter was observed in Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs evidently due to deposited Ag-NPs layer over the surface of these materials. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze chemical states of the elements in Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs as shown in Fig. 5. Fig. 5(a) reveals the presence of Ti2p peaks namely Ti2p 3/2 and Ti2p 1/2 located at 458.06 eV and 363.79 eV, respectively, corresponds to Ti 4 oxidation state or titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ).The Ag3d spectrum with BE regions centered at 367. 55 eV (3d 5/2 ) and 373.53 eV (3d 3/2 ), indicating the presence of silver in metal state as depicted in Fig. 5(b) 12.Fig. 5(c) shows the O1 s spectrum with main components, one at 530.87 eV, ascribed to the lattice oxygen O 2 and binding energy component located at 532.98 eV related to metal-OH bonds or free hydroxyl group (OA AH) on the surface.The spectrum of C 1 s with peaks located at 284.60 eV and 288.44 eV are presented in Fig. 5(d).The main peak at 284.60 eV is assigned to CA AC and CA AH hydrocarbon bonds.The peak at 288.44 eV can be attributed to carbon atoms bound to oxygen with double bond C14O.The relative concentration of peak at 284.60 eV was much more and may be recognized as the carbon from carbon tap used for sample analysis 21. UV-vis diffuse reflectance absorbance spectra of TiO 2 NWs and Ag-NPs modified TiO 2 NWs are shown in Fig. 6.Fig. 6(a) shows the UV-vis diffuse reflectance absorbance spectra of TiO 2 NWs and Ag-NPs modified TiO 2 NWs.Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs shows a broad visible light absorption due to LSPR absorption of Ag-NPs, indicating metallic Ag exists as recognized by XPS and TEM analysis.More importantly, LSPR images could be seen in Ag-NPs loaded TiO 2 NWs samples, when excited with a laser light of wavelength 532 nm, as depicted in the inset of Fig. 6(b).The band gap energy was calculated according to plot of (ahv) 2 vs. photon energy as depicted in Fig. 6(c).The band gap energy of 3.10, 3.17 and 3.16 eV was obtained for TiO 2 , TiO 2 NWs and Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs, respectively.The TiO 2 band gap energy has increased perhaps due to the pure anatase phase and larger crystallite size of TiO 2 NWs compared to TiO 2 nanoparticles.Ag-NPs have no significant influence on increasing the band gap energy of TiO 2 NWs.However, enhanced visible light absorption evidenced due to a broadband peak located at around 580 nm arising from SPR of Ag-NPs in the TiO 2 matrix.Fig. 7 shows PL emission spectra of the pure TiO 2 NWs and Ag-NPs modified TiO 2 NWs samples excited at a wavelength of 532 nm.The broad symmetric peaks appeared at 536 nm revealed that emission is not because of TiO 2 band edge excitation.Therefore, PL signals can be attributed to the transition of electrons from the oxygen vacancies to TiO 2 valance band.It is noticeable that emission spectra of the Ag-modified TiO 2 samples are similar to those of the pure TiO 2 NWs sample.However, the PL intensity enfeebled in Ag-NPs sample.The electron transfers from the TiO 2 NWs to Ag-promoted TiO 2 NWs are more efficient, resulting in hindered charges recombination rate. The control experiments for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with H 2 were conducted at 100 C for 2 h under visible light irradiation.Using all types of catalysts, carbon containing compounds were not detected in the reaction system without reactants or light irradiations.The effects of Ag-NPs on TiO 2 NWs performance for CO 2 photoreduction with H 2 to CO is shown in Fig. 8(a).Pure TiO 2 has low photoactivity for CO production, which gradually increased using TiO 2 NWs.This was perhaps due to efficient charges transfer and higher surface area in TiO 2 NWs.Loading Ag-NPs into TiO 2 NWs significantly improved CO 2 photoreduction with optimum Ag-NPs contents of 3 wt..However, with higher Ag-loading (e.g. 5 wt.) photoactivity was reduced, possibly Ag-NPs were adjacent to each other over TiO 2 NWs, electron-hole charges recombine immediately, resulting in lower photoactivity 12.The significantly enhanced photoactivity of Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs samples were evidently due to plasmonic effect with efficient charges separation by Ag-NPs 40. The performance of Ag-NP on the photoactivity of TiO 2 NWs for photocatalytic CO 2 conversion with H 2 to CH 4 and CH 3 OH is presented in Fig. 8(b).Using pure TiO 2 NWs, only small amount of CH 4 was produced which was considerably enhanced in Ag-NPs loading TiO 2 NWs samples.The maximum yield of CH 4 was detected at optimum Ag-NPs-loading of 3 wt.and then gradually declined.On the other hand, CH 3 OH production was not detected in the pure TiO 2 but its production was evidenced in all the Ag-NPs loaded TiO 2 NWs samples.The Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs exhibits higher photoactivity for CO 2 reduction, where the yield of CH 3 OH was increased gradually by increasing the contents of Ag-NPs.The optimal 3 wt.Ag-loading was observed and its production trends were similar to that of CH 4 production.These observations have confirmed that plasmon-excited electron can be injected into TiO 2 for its excitation.On the other hand, an instant charge separation can be achieved on the Ag-NPs due to synergistic effect resulting in prolonged recombination time of the photo-generated charges.In this way, enhanced photoactivity could be achieved for visible light driven reduction of CO 2 to CO, CH 4 and CH 3 OH.The yield rates of different products are presented in Table 2. The yield of CO over Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs was 983 mmole gcatal.A1 h A1 , a 23 times more than TiO 2 NWs and 109 times higher than TiO 2 .It is likely to see that 13 mmole g-catal.A1 h A1 of CH 3 OH was produced over Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs but was not detected in TiO 2 and TiO 2 NWs.These revealed Ag-NPs are also favorable for CH 3 OH production.The selectivity of CO production over Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs increased to 98, confirming selective CO 2 reduction using H 2 as a reducing agent.The CO 2 and H 2 conversions over Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs were 1.43 and 2.35, respectively.It is remarkable to see that the conversion of H 2 was higher in Ag-loaded TiO 2 NWs samples.According to the stoichiometric reaction in Eq. ( 1), one mole of H 2 is required to produce one mole of CO. As the selectivity of CO is near to 98, suggesting CO 2 and H 2 consumption would be approximately much closer.Conversely, the higher H 2 conversion during CO 2 photo-reduction with H 2 over plasmonic Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs was certainly due to some amount of hydrogen consumed by the silver during its oxidation/reduction process under light irradiations 41.Therefore, enhanced photoactivity of Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs was mainly governed by the visible light absorption, higher surface area, photo-generated charges separation and SPR effect of Ag-NPs 13. In order to investigate the performance of selective CO 2 photoreduction to CO by H 2 reducing agent over core-shell Ag NPs/TiO 2 NWs photocatalysts under visible light irradiations, the results are compared with the work reported by various researchers.Kong et al. 12 reported CO 2 reduction with H 2 O over Ag/TiO 2 nanorods with CH 4 yield of 2.64 mmole g.catal A1 h A1 , a 5 fold higher than TiO 2 nanorods.CO 2 reduction with H 2 O to CO was reported over g-C 3 N 4 -N-TiO 2 in batch mode operation with a maximum yield 14.73 mmole after 12 h irradiation time 42.Over I/TiO 2 and Cu-I/TiO 2 , a CO yield rate of 3.9 and 12 mmole g-catal.A1 was reported after 3.5 h during gas phase CO 2 reduction in a batch mode operation 43.However, in current study, CO 2 reduction with H 2 to CO at selectivity 98 significantly enhanced using Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs core/shell hetero-junction.A comparison study between previous reports and current study revealed significantly improved photoactivity and selectivity using Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs photocatalysts. The efficiency of Ag-NPs modified TiO 2 NWs was further examined based on the quantum yield, calculated for each experiment, as the ratio of the product rate (mole per sec) with photonic flux (mole per sec).The quantum yield of CO 2 photoreduction can be defined as the ratio of amount of products (mole per sec) with photonic flux (mole per sec) as shown in Eq. ( 2) 44. Quantum yield 14 n A production rate molsec moles of photon flux molsec A 100 2 The quantum yield was calculated based on 2, 6 and 8 electrons (n) used for CO, CH 3 OH and CH 4 production rate and moles of photon input energy over the catalyst surface.The quantum yields (QY) of CO, CH 3 OH and CH 4 production over 3 wt.Ag-NPs/TiO 2 NWs were 0.15, 0.01 and 0.006, respectively (Table 1).The significantly enhanced QY over Ag-NPs/TiO 2 was evidently due to efficient charge transfer rate and SPR effect of Ag-NPs.
